'Miconazole' is an imidazole antifungal agent, developed by Janssen
Pharmaceutica, commonly applied topically to the skin or to mucus membranes to
cure fungal infections. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of ergosterol, a
critical component of fungal cell membranes. It can also be used against certain
species of [[Leishmania]] protozoa which are a type of unicellular parasite that
also contain ergosterol in their cell membranes. In addition to its antifungal
and antiparasitic actions, it also has some limited antibacterial properties. It
is marketed in various formulations under various brand names.

Miconazole is also used in Ektachrome film developing in the final rinse of the
Kodak E-6 process and similar Fuji CR-56 process, replacing formaldehyde. Fuji
Hunt also includes miconazole as a final rinse additive in their formulation of
the C-41RA rapid access color negative developing process.
